awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Advancing Multidimensional Data Science via New Algebraic Models and Scalable Algorithms
awd_abstract_narration:
Building upon the rapid advancements in monitoring, networking and sensing technologies, most modern data collected are inherently multidimensional in nature, that is, each datum is influenced by a variety of factors. For example, a pixel in a remote sensing video is a function of time, color (wavelength) and spatial location. Another contemporary example comes from the widely used rating and recommendation systems, where a rating depends on the user, user demographic, product being rated and time. In fact, this is the case for numerous other applications such as cellular network performance statistics, geophysical systems for earth sciences, and education statistics in interactive learning and collaboration environments. This research addresses the need to advance data science for reliable and scalable information acquisition and processing for these complex and large-scale multidimensional data.
 
In particular, the research builds and investigates a novel linear and multilinear algebraic framework to model multidimensional data. Using this framework one can tap into the well-developed body of vector space methods and adapt them to process multidimensional data in a principled manner to realize orders of magnitude performance gains over current methods.  The research also addresses the challenges, which arise in deploying the framework for large-scale applications and investigates numerical and memory efficient algorithms. Integration of research and education is enabled through new cross-cutting curriculum development, continued undergraduate mentoring, and through integration of the research outcomes with existing undergraduate curriculum. The broader impacts are realized through a number of collaborative efforts involving, Tufts Interactive Learning and Collaboration Environment (InterLACE) program, Brigham and Women?s Hospital and AT&T research.

por.por_cntn:
The research project was carried out under two broad categories over two periods with a significant impact on advancing science and technology and supporting education and mentoring in STEM areas. 

From 2017-2020 the topic of the research was on developing theoretical models and algorithms to learn and utilize parsimonious representation of tensors which is data that is multidimensional in that it is indexed by several independent variables, such as hyper-spectral videos that are composed of 3D (space) + wavelength (color) + time, seismic data for geo-exploration comprised of 4D (set of transmitters and receivers in 2D) + time, and dynamic magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) data made up of 3D spatial frequency + time. In technical terms, the research developed novel low-rank factorizations of such data types advancing the general framework of multi-linear algebra. Our models and methods yielded state-of-the-art results for these applications enabling rapid and resource-constrained sub-surface sensing/imaging, robust anomaly removal, unsupervised clustering, and data imputation (completion/prediction of missing entries) that are critical to further science and technology in the respective application domains. 

This project was undertaken by two PhD students and several Undergraduate (UG) students as NSF REUs with peer-reviewed publications, PhD theses, codes, and technical reports. 

From 2020-2023, the topic of research shifted to utilizing models and methods from optimal transport (OT) for high-dimensional statistics and machine learning and their applications to several domains. Optimal transport is a classical problem related to studying the efficient (optimal) movement of goods from source of production to places of consumption highlighting the duality between pricing, supply-demand, and cost of transportation. Mathematically the problem can also be abstracted as the minimal cost of moving a pile of mass from one shape into another ? akin to a potter shaping a pile of mud into a cup. This seemingly simple framework captures many real-world phenomena from economics, fluid flow to control, and statistical learning. In this project, we used the theory of OT to develop novel models for multivariate time-series data with transitory behavior for unsupervised segmentation, novel high-dimensional goodness-of-fit tests to detect changes and learning generative models for bio-statistics applications, robust machine learning with applications to learning classifiers that work with new data in absence of any labels and learning useful features by self-supervision mechanisms, and learning representation and analysis of a novel class of datatypes namely, data as distributions, that arise in natural language processing, image processing using point cloud representations, and single-cell RNA/Omics data. Other applications include high energy physics, efficient control of traffic congestion, and multiview radar imaging.

Our work significantly advances the state-of-the-art in all these diverse applications yielding novel insights leading to new pertinent open problems.

This project was undertaken by two PhD and one MS student with peer-reviewed publications, public code repositories, and technical reports.
